org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang

Class XMLTypeAndOpsTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • junit.framework.Assert
      • junit.framework.TestCase
        • org.apache.derbyTesting.junit.BaseTestCase
          • org.apache.derbyTesting.junit.BaseJDBCTestCase
            • org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.XMLTypeAndOpsTest
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    junit.framework.Test

    public final class XMLTypeAndOpsTest
extends BaseJDBCTestCase
    XMLTypeAndOpsTest this test is the JUnit equivalent to what used to be the "lang/xml_general.sql" test, which was canon-based. Since the .sql test had different masters for embedded, JCC, and Derby Client, and since it performed some "sed'ing" to ensure consistent results across JVMs, it was not sufficient to just wrap the test in a JUnit ScriptTestCase (because ScriptTestCase doesn't deal with multiple masters nor with sed'ing). Hence the creation of this pure JUnit version of the test.

    • Method Detail

      • suite

        public static junit.framework.Test suite()
        Return a suite that runs a set of tests which are meant to be the equivalent to the test cases in the old xml_general.sql. But only return such a suite IF the testing classpath has the required XML classes. Otherwise just return an empty suite.

      • testXMLColCreation

        public void testXMLColCreation()
                        throws java.lang.Exception

        Throws:

      • testIllegalNullInserts

        public void testIllegalNullInserts()
                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Check insertion of null values into XML columns. This test just checks the negative cases--i.e. cases where we expect the insertions to fail. The positive cases are tested implicitly as part of XMLTestSetup.setUp() when we load the test data.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testXMLColsWithNonXMLVals

        public void testXMLColsWithNonXMLVals()
                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Test insertion of non-XML values into XML columns. These should all fail because such an operation is not allowed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

                    throws java.lang.Exception

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testXMLInNonXMLOps

        public void testXMLInNonXMLOps()
                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Try to use XML values in non-XML operations. These should all fail (the only operations allowed with XML are the specified XML operations (xmlparse, xmlserialize, xmlexists, xmlquery)).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testXMLComparisons

        public void testXMLComparisons()
                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Test simple comparisons with XML. These should all fail because no such comparisons are allowed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testIllegalOps

        public void testIllegalOps()
                    throws java.lang.Exception
        Test additional restrictions on use of XML values. These should all fail.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testTriggerSetXML

        public void testTriggerSetXML()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Test use of XML columns in a trigger's "SET" clause. Should work so long as the target value has type XML.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testXMLParse

        public void testXMLParse()
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Various tests for the XMLPARSE operator. Note that this test primarily checks the negative cases--i.e. cases where we expect the XMLPARSE op to fail. The positive cases were tested implicitly as part of XMLTestSetup.setUp() when we loaded the test data.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testIsNull

        public void testIsNull()
                throws java.lang.Exception

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • testTopLevelSelect

        public void testTopLevelSelect()
                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Derby doesn't currently support XML values in a top-level result set. So make sure that doesn't work. These should all fail.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
